title-group.article-title: Therapeutic Potential of TLR8 Agonist GS‚Äê9688 (Selgantolimod) in Chronic Hepatitis B: Remodeling of Antiviral and Regulatory Mediators

aff.named-content: Institute for Liver and Digestive Health

article-meta.aff: 7Present address: Ideaya Biosciences Inc.South San FranciscoCA

author-notes.corresp:

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ License, which permits use, distribution and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited.

sec.title: Background and Aims
sec.p: GS‚Äê9688 (selgantolimod) is a toll‚Äêlike receptor 8 agonist in clinical development for the treatment of chronic hepatitis B (CHB). Antiviral activity of GS‚Äê9688 has previously been evaluated in vitro in HBV‚Äêinfected hepatocytes and in vivo in the woodchuck model of CHB. Here we evaluated the potential of GS‚Äê9688 to boost responses contributing to viral control and to modulate regulatory mediators.

sec.title: Approach and Results
sec.p: We characterized the effect of GS‚Äê9688 on immune cell subsets in vitro in peripheral blood mononuclear cells of healthy controls and patients with CHB. GS‚Äê9688 activated dendritic cells and mononuclear phagocytes to produce IL‚Äê12 and other immunomodulatory mediators, inducing a comparable cytokine profile in healthy controls and patients with CHB. GS‚Äê9688 increased the frequency of activated natural killer (NK) cells, mucosal‚Äêassociated invariant T cells, CD4+ follicular helper T cells, and, in about 50% of patients, HBV‚Äêspecific CD8+ T cells expressing interferon‚ÄêŒ≥. Moreover, in vitro stimulation with GS‚Äê9688 induced NK‚Äêcell expression of interferon‚ÄêŒ≥ and TNF‚ÄêŒ±, and promoted hepatocyte lysis. We also assessed whether GS‚Äê9688 inhibited immunosuppressive cell subsets that might enhance antiviral efficacy. Stimulation with GS‚Äê9688 reduced the frequency of CD4+ regulatory T cells and monocytic myeloid‚Äêderived suppressor cells (MDSCs). Residual MDSCs expressed higher levels of negative immune regulators, galectin‚Äê9 and programmed death‚Äêligand 1. Conversely, GS‚Äê9688 induced an expansion of immunoregulatory TNF‚Äêrelated apoptosis‚Äêinducing ligand+ NK cells and degranulation of arginase‚ÄêI+ polymorphonuclear MDSCs.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: GS‚Äê9688 induces cytokines in human peripheral blood mononuclear cells that are able to activate antiviral effector function by multiple immune mediators (HBV‚Äêspecific CD8+ T cells, CD4+ follicular helper T cells, NK cells, and mucosal‚Äêassociated invariant T cells). Although reducing the frequency of some immunoregulatory subsets, it enhances the immunosuppressive potential of others, highlighting potential biomarkers and immunotherapeutic targets to optimize the antiviral efficacy of GS‚Äê9688.

fn.p: Potential conflict of interest: Dr. Khan is employed by Gilead. Dr. Daffis is employed and owns stock in Gilead. Dr. Ramakrishnan is employed and owns stock in Gilead. Dr. Pattabiraman is employed and owns stock in Gilead. Dr. Chu is employed and owns stock in Gilead. Dr. Steuer owns stock in Gilead. Dr. Peiser is employed and owns stock in Bristol‚ÄêMyers Squibb. Dr. Palazzo is employed and owns stock in Gilead. Dr. Frey owns stock in Gilead. Dr. Javanbakht is employed and owns stock in SQZ Biotechnologies and owns stock in Gilead and Roche. Dr. Fletcher is employed and owns stock in Gilead. Dr. Maini consults and received grants from Gilead, Hoffman La Roche, and Immunocore. Dr. Pallett consults and received grants from Gilead.

body.p: Accordingly, in this study we have evaluated the immunomodulatory effects of GS‚Äê9688 on various immune cells in vitro using freshly isolated peripheral leukocytes from healthy controls and patients with CHB, to understand its therapeutic potential for CHB.

sec.title: Ethical Approval
sec.p: This study was approved by the local ethics board of Brighton & Sussex (Research Ethics Committee [REC] ref: 11/LO/0421), London Brent (REC ref: 17/LO/0266), and University College London‚ÄìRoyal Free Biobank (REC ref: 16/WA/0289). All participants gave written, informed consent. In select experiments, whole blood was obtained from AllCells (Alameda, CA) and the MT Group (Van Nuys, CA). In this instance, consent was obtained from the donor or donor‚Äôs legal next of kin using internal review board‚Äìapproved authorizations. Study protocols conformed to the 1975 Declaration of Helsinki guidelines, and samples/data were stored in compliance with the Data Protection Act 1998 & Human Tissue Act 2004.

sec.title: Study Cohort
sec.p: All participants were anti‚ÄêHCV and anti‚ÄêHIV antibody negative. Healthy controls were additionally anti‚ÄêHBV negative. Participants with CHB were stratified by HBV viral load (IU/mL; determined by real‚Äêtime PCR), HBsAg titer (IU/mL; determined by Architect; Abbott Laboratories, London, United Kingdom), HBeAg positivity, and serum alanine transaminase (ALT; IU/L) where appropriate (Supporting Table S1).

sec.title: Investigational Drug
PBMC Isolation
sec.p: PBMCs were isolated using Pancoll (PanBiotech GmbH, Aidenbach, Germany) or Ficoll (GE Healthcare Sciences, Chicago, IL) by density centrifugation from heparinized blood. Cells were washed and resuspended in Roswell Park Memorial Institute 1640 medium (Life Technologies, Carlsbad, CA) containing 10% vol/vol heat‚Äêinactivated fetal bovine serum (HI‚ÄêFBS, Sigma‚ÄêAldrich, St. Louis, MO; or Hyclone, GE Healthcare Sciences), 100¬†U/mL penicillin/streptomycin, 4‚Äê(2‚Äêhydroxyethyl)‚Äê1‚Äêpiperazine ethanesulfonic acid, Œ≤‚Äêmercaptoethanol, and essential and non‚Äêessential amino acids (cRPMI; all Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA).

sec.title: Measurement of Cytokines by Luminex
sec.p: A total of 1¬†√ó¬†106 PBMCs/well were seeded in 96‚Äêwell round‚Äêbottom plates in 200¬†¬µL cRPMI with GS‚Äê9688 or ‚â§0.1% DMSO vehicle control, at 37¬∞C. After 24¬†hours, culture supernatants were harvested and stored at ‚àí80¬∞C. Cytokine concentrations were determined by Luminex array (Bio‚ÄêPlex 200 System; Bio‚ÄêRad Laboratories, Hercules, CA) or MAGPIX (Luminex Corporation, Austin, TX) with the following kits: Th1/Th2 cytokine panel (eBioscience, Inc., San Diego, CA), cytokine discovery fixed 45‚Äêplex (Bio‚ÄêTechne, Minneapolis, MN) and a single‚Äêplex IL‚Äê12/IL‚Äê23p40 (ProcartaPlex; eBioscience, Inc.).

sec.title: In Vitro Expansion and Detection of HBV‚ÄêSpecific T Cells
sec.p: Approximately 0.5‚Äê1¬†√ó106 PBMCs/well were seeded in 96‚Äêwell round‚Äêbottom plates in cRPMI for 7‚Äê14¬†days, at 37¬∞C. Cells were stimulated with 1¬†¬µg/mL pan‚Äêgenotypic overlapping 15‚Äêmer peptides spanning the HBcAg overlapping peptide (OLP) (provided by Gilead Sciences Inc.) with GS‚Äê9688 or ‚â§0.1% DMSO vehicle control from 0¬†days. Cells were maintained in 20¬†IU/mL recombinant human (rh)‚ÄêIL‚Äê2 (Peprotech, London, United Kingdom) and continually supplemented throughout the expansion period. Cells were restimulated with HBV‚ÄêOLP for the final 16¬†hours in the presence of 1¬†¬µg/mL Brefeldin‚ÄêA (Sigma‚ÄêAldrich) and Monensin (GolgiStop; BD Biosciences, San Jose, CA) at 37¬∞C, before analysis by flow cytometry (described subsequently). Where appropriate, replicate wells were pooled before restimulation. Alternatively, HBV‚Äêspecific CD8+ T cells were expanded using 0.1¬†¬µg/mL ProMix HBV‚ÄêOLP, 15‚Äêmer peptide pool of nine human leukocyte antigen (HLA)‚ÄêA2/A11/A24‚Äêrestricted peptides (ProImmune, Oxford, United Kingdom), or 1¬†¬µM HBV‚Äêderived HLA‚ÄêA2‚Äêrestricted peptides (core FLPSDFFPSV; envelope FLLTRILTI, WLSLLVPFV, LLVPFVQWFV, and GLSPTVWLSV; polymerase GLSRYVARL and KLHLYSHPI [ProImmune]). HBV‚Äêspecific CD8+ T cells were detected using HLA‚Äêspecific multimers, pooled as appropriate for each patient HLA and multimer type. Briefly, after expansion, cells were resuspended in multimer wash buffer (1¬†√ó¬†PBS with 2% human AB serum; Life Technologies), containing a pool of HLA‚Äêrestricted multimers (Supporting Table S2). Cells were stained with multimers for 15¬†minutes, at 37¬∞C, before monoclonal antibody (mAb) staining for flow cytometric analysis.

sec.title: Multiparametric Flow Cytometry
sec.p: For all flow cytometric analysis, cells were washed before staining in 1¬†√ó¬†PBS. Cells were first stained with a fixable cell viability dye then stained with mAbs (Supporting Table S3) in brilliant violet buffer (BD Biosciences) for 30¬†minutes. Once stained, cells were washed and fixed with BDCytofix (BD Biosciences) for 20¬†minutes at 4¬∞C. For intracellular antigens, cells were fixed and permeabilized using BDCytofix/Cytoperm and further stained with mAbs against intracellular antigens in 0.1% wt/vol Saponin (Sigma‚ÄêAldrich). For intranuclear antigens, cells were fixed and permeabilized using the human forkhead box P3 (FOXP3) buffer (BD Biosciences), and further stained with mAbs targeting intranuclear antigens in 1¬†√ó¬†PBS for 30¬†minutes at 4¬∞C. Samples were acquired on a LSRFortessaX20, and data analyzed using FlowJo (v.10.4.1; BD Biosciences). Single stain controls and anti‚Äêmouse immunoglobulin G (IgG) CompBeads (BD Biosciences) were used where appropriate.

sec.title: Assessment of Mononuclear Phagocytes, cDCs, and Plasmacytoid Dendritic Cell Phenotype and Function
sec.p: A total of 1¬†√ó¬†106 PBMCs/well were seeded in 96‚Äêwell flat‚Äêbottom plates in cRPMI with GS‚Äê9688 or ‚â§0.1% DMSO vehicle control at 37¬∞C. After 2¬†hours, cells were treated with 50% vol/vol BDGolgiPlug (BD Biosciences) diluted in 1¬†√ó¬†PBS and incubated at 37¬∞C for 6¬†hours. Cells were then harvested and stained for flow cytometric analysis.

sec.title: Assessment of MAIT and NK Cell Phenotype and Function
sec.p: A total of 0.5‚Äê1¬†√ó¬†106 PBMCs/well were seeded in 96‚Äêwell round‚Äêbottom plates in cRPMI with GS‚Äê9688 or ‚â§0.1% DMSO vehicle control at 37¬∞C. After 18¬†hours, cells were resuspended in fresh cRPMI supplemented with 5¬†Œºg/mL Brefeldin‚ÄêA and 5¬†Œºg/mL BDGolgiStop and incubated for a further 5¬†hours. Cells were then harvested, stained with a panel of mAbs (Supporting Table S3), and analyzed by flow cytometry. For cytokine blocking, cells were treated with 10¬†¬µg/mL neutralizing antibodies against IL‚Äê12p70 (clone:24910; R&D Systems, Inc., Minneapolis, MN), IL‚Äê18 (clone 125‚Äê2H; MBL USA Corp., Ottawa, IL), or isotype control IgG1 (clone 11711; R&D Systems, Inc.).

sec.title: HepG2 Lysis Assay
sec.p: NK cell cytolytic activity was assessed using a fluorescence‚Äêbased killing assay (DELFIA ETDA Cytotoxicity Assay; PerkinElmer, Waltham, MA). PBMCs were treated with GS‚Äê9688 or ‚â§0.1% DMSO vehicle control at 37¬∞C. After 16¬†hours, NK cells were isolated by negative selection (StemCell Technologies, Kent, WA). HepG2 cells (HCC cell line [HB‚Äê8065]; ATCC, Manassas, VA) were loaded with the intracellular‚Äêspecific fluorescence‚Äêenhancing ligand BATDA and incubated for 30¬†minutes. HepG2 were co‚Äêcultured with pretreated, purified NK cells at a 1:10 target‚Äêto‚Äêeffector ratio in V‚Äêbottomed plates and incubated for a further 2¬†hours. Culture supernatants were then harvested and extracellular release of BATDA was assessed by fluorescence activity using Europium solution, measured by a time‚Äêresolved fluorometer (VICTOR, PerkinElmer).

sec.title: Assessment of TREG and CD4+ Follicular Helper T‚ÄêCell Frequency, Phenotype, and Function
sec.p: A total of 0.5‚Äê1¬†√ó¬†106 PBMCs/well were seeded in 96‚Äêwell round‚Äêbottom plates in cRPMI and stimulated with GS‚Äê9688 or ‚â§0.1% DMSO vehicle control at 37¬∞C for 7¬†days. Cells were maintained in 500¬†IU/mL rhIL‚Äê2, continually supplemented throughout. After 7¬†days, cells were harvested and analyzed by flow cytometry.

sec.title: Assessment of MDSC Frequency, Phenotype, and Function
sec.p: A total of 1¬†√ó¬†106 freshly isolated PBMCs were stained to determine ex vivo frequencies of MDSC subsets by flow cytometry. To determine the effect of GS‚Äê9688 on MDSC frequencies in the short term, 1‚Äê2¬†√ó¬†106 PBMCs/well were seeded in 48‚Äêwell plates in cRPMI and cultured for 24¬†hours with GS‚Äê9688 or ‚â§0.1% DMSO vehicle control at 37¬∞C. Following incubation, cells were harvested for analysis by flow cytometry. Culture supernatants were stored at ‚àí80¬∞ for analysis of extracellular arginase‚ÄêI by ELISA (Hycult Biotech, Uden, the Netherlands).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: The Emax defines the maximum cytokine level induced by GS‚Äê9688. The minimal effective concentration (MEC) defines the concentration of GS‚Äê9688 corresponding to three‚Äêfold induction of cytokine above background (DMSO control). EC50 defines the concentration of GS‚Äê9688 giving 50% of the maximal response. MEC and EC50 were calculated using the Pipeline Pilot v.9.2 (BIOVIA, San Diego, CA). All statistical analyses were performed in Prism (v.7.0e; GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA); tests used are indicated in figure legends (Wilcoxon signed‚Äêrank t test; Kruskal‚ÄêWallis test; Friedman test [ANOVA] with Dunn‚Äôs post hoc test; and ANOVA with Sidak‚Äôs post hoc test). All tests were carried out as two‚Äêtailed tests. Significant differences are denoted in all figures and defined as *P¬†<¬†0.05, **P¬†<¬†0.01, ***P¬†<¬†0.001, and ****P¬†<¬†0.0001.

sec.title: In Vitro Stimulation of Human PBMC From Healthy Controls and Patients With CHB With GS‚Äê9688 Produces Immunomodulatory Mediators

caption.p: In vitro stimulation with GS‚Äê9688 induces secretion of immunomodulatory cytokines by cDCs and MNPs. (A) Experimental design: evaluation of GS‚Äê9688‚Äêinduced soluble mediators by multiplex array. (B) Concentration of cytokines from PBMC culture supernatants of healthy controls stimulated for 24¬†hours with 0.156¬†¬µM GS‚Äê9688 or vehicle control (DMSO). Bars represents mean ¬± SEM; circle radius represents absolute expression; and filled‚Äêin circles represent a significant difference between treatment groups (n¬†=¬†10; Mann‚ÄêWhitney U test). (C) Levels of IL‚Äê12p40/IL‚Äê18/IL‚Äê6/TNF‚ÄêŒ±/IFN‚ÄêŒ≥/IFN‚ÄêŒ± following GS‚Äê9688 treatment, serial‚Äêdiluted from 10¬†¬µM, from PBMCs isolated from healthy controls (n¬†=¬†10) and patients with CHB (n¬†=¬†10). Data indicate the mean¬†¬±¬†SEM. Representative flow cytometric plots (left) and percentage of IL‚Äê12p40+ cells (D) and TNFŒ±+ cells (E) by circulating MNPs (Lin1+CD14+), cDCs (Lin1‚àíHLA‚ÄêDR+CD123‚àíCD11c+), and pDCs (Lin1‚àíHLA‚ÄêDR+CD123+CD11c‚àí) from GS‚Äê9688 treated healthy control PBMC (n¬†=¬†6). Data represent the mean ¬± SEM. Abbreviations: GM‚ÄêCSF, granulocyte‚Äêmacrophage colony‚Äêstimulating factor; SSC‚ÄêA, side scatter‚Äìarea.

sec.title: GS‚Äê9688 Activates cDCs and Mononuclear Phagocytes to Produce IL‚Äê12p40 and TNF‚ÄêŒ±
Frequencies of Functional HBV‚ÄêSpecific CD8+ T Cells Increase in a Subset of Patients With CHB After In Vitro Stimulation With GS‚Äê9688

caption.p: GS‚Äê9688 increases HBV‚Äêspecific CD8+ T‚Äêcell frequency and function in a subset of patients with CHB. HBV‚Äêspecific CD8+ T cells were expanded from PBMCs by stimulation with pan‚Äêgenotypic, overlapping peptides spanning the HBV‚Äêcore protein (OLP) in the presence of 0.1¬†¬µM GS‚Äê9688 or vehicle control (DMSO). Representative flow cytometric plots of a ‚Äúresponder‚Äù and ‚Äúnon‚Äêresponder‚Äù to GS‚Äê9688 treatment (A) and percentage of IFN‚ÄêŒ≥‚Äêproducing HBV‚Äêspecific CD8+ T cells for individual patients (B). The percentage of IFN‚ÄêŒ≥ produced by DMSO‚Äêtreated CD8+ T cells was subtracted to determine HBV‚Äêspecific cytokine production (n¬†=¬†28). Heat map denotes fold change in percentage of IFN‚ÄêŒ≥ production with GS‚Äê9688. (C) Representative flow cytometric plots (left) and percentage of HBV‚Äêspecific CD8+ T cells identified by staining with a panel of immunodominant HBV‚Äêspecific HLA‚Äêrestricted multimers (see Supporting Table S2) after in vitro expansion with a pool of HBV‚Äêderived HLA‚Äêrestricted peptides¬†¬±¬†0.156¬†¬µM GS‚Äê9688 or DMSO (n¬†=¬†23; Wilcoxon Signed‚Äêrank t test). (D) MFI of IFN‚ÄêŒ≥ produced in response to HBV‚Äêcore OLP (n¬†=¬†21). (E) Percentage of CD8+ T cells co‚Äêproducing IFN‚ÄêŒ≥ and TNF‚ÄêŒ± in response to HBV‚Äêcore OLP (n¬†=¬†28). (F) Stratification of patient non‚Äêresponders and responders (defined as a ‚â•1.2‚Äêfold increase in percentage of IFN‚ÄêŒ≥+ HBV‚Äêspecific CD8+ T cells in response to HBV‚Äêcore OLP in the presence of 0.1¬†¬µM GS‚Äê9688) by baseline HBsAg titer (n¬†=¬†23). Clinical characteristics of all patients with CHB are detailed in Supporting Table S1. Error bars represent the mean ¬± SEM. **P¬†<¬†0.01.

sec.p: Finally, we explored whether the heterogeneity in the magnitude of the HBV‚Äêspecific T‚Äêcell response to GS‚Äê9688 was associated with any clinical parameters in our cohort. In doing so, we noted that a baseline HBsAg titer less than 2,000¬†IU/mL was associated with an increase in the proportion of IFN‚ÄêŒ≥‚Äêproducing HBV‚Äêspecific T cells in the presence of GS‚Äê9688 (Fig. 2F). In contrast, most patients denoted ‚Äúnon‚Äêresponders‚Äù (who did not have an increase in the frequency of IFN‚ÄêŒ≥+ HBV‚Äêspecific CD8+ T cells with GS‚Äê9688) had a baseline HBsAg titer greater than 2,000¬†IU/mL (Fig. 2F). No clear association in responsiveness was seen with serum ALT levels or HBV viral load (Supporting Fig. S2C).

sec.title: Treatment of PBMCs With GS‚Äê9688 Potentiates the Activation and Function of Antiviral Effectors

caption.p: In vitro stimulation with GS‚Äê9688 increases the cytolytic and noncytolytic potential of NK cells, while increasing TRAIL expression on the CD56bright subset. PBMCs from healthy controls (HC) or patients with CHB were treated in vitro with GS‚Äê9688 (dose range or single dose) or vehicle control (DMSO) for 24¬†hours. (A) Representative flow cytometric plots, percentages of CD69 and HLA‚ÄêDR, and MFI of CD38 expression (CHB; all n¬†=¬†20; Friedman test [ANOVA] with a Dunn‚Äôs multiple comparisons test). (B) Percentage of TNF‚ÄêŒ±+ (0.156¬†¬µM; HC; n¬†=¬†8) and IFN‚ÄêŒ≥+ (0.156¬†¬µM; HC; n¬†=¬†14; Wilcoxon signed‚Äêrank t test) ¬± neutralization of IL‚Äê12/IL‚Äê18 or isotype control (0.156¬†¬µM; HC; n¬†=¬†6; Wilcoxon signed‚Äêrank t test). (C) Percentage of perforin+ (0.156¬†¬µM; HC; n¬†=¬†14) and granzyme B (0.156¬†¬µM; HC; n¬†=¬†8; Wilcoxon signed‚Äêrank t test). (D) Percentage of CD107a+ (0.156¬†¬µM; HC; n¬†=¬†22; Wilcoxon signed‚Äêrank t test) on global CD3‚àíCD56+ NK cells. (E) Schematic of experimental setup and percentage of cell lysis of HepG2 hepatoma cell line (target cell) following co‚Äêculture with purified NK cells pretreated with DMSO or GS‚Äê9688 (0.2¬†¬µM; HC; n¬†=¬†6; Wilcoxon signed‚Äêrank t test). (F) Representative flow cytometric plots (left) and percentage of TRAIL expression on global CD3‚àíCD56+ NK cells and CD56bright NK cells (0.1¬†¬µM; CHB; n¬†=¬†20; Wilcoxon signed‚Äêrank t test). Error bars represent the mean ¬± SEM. **P¬†<¬†0.01; ***P¬†<¬†0.001; ****P¬†<¬†0.0001.

sec.p: Together, these data demonstrate that GS‚Äê9688 can enhance the cytolytic and noncytolytic activity of multiple innate effectors in vitro.

sec.title: In Vitro GS‚Äê9688 Reduces the Frequency of TREG and Increases the Frequency of Circulating Follicular Helper CD4+ T Cells

caption.p: GS‚Äê9688 increases the frequency of cTFH and decreases the frequency of TREG. (A) Representative flow cytometric plots (left) and percentage of cTFH (CD4+CXCR5+PD‚Äê1+; healthy controls (HC); n¬†=¬†12) as a proportion of global CD3+CD8‚àíCD4+ T cells after 7¬†days of in vitro stimulation with GS‚Äê9688 (dose range). Representative flow cytometric plots and summary data depicting ICOS expression (MFI; n¬†=¬†12) (B) and percentage of CD4+ TREG (CD4+CD127loCD25hiFOXP3+; CHB/HC; n¬†=¬†37) as a proportion of global CD3+CD8‚àíCD4+ T cells after in vitro stimulation with GS‚Äê9688 (dose range) (C). Representative flow cytometric plots and summary data depicting CTLA‚Äê4 (percentage and MFI; n¬†=¬†8/14) (D) and CD39 (percentage and MFI; n¬†=¬†8/14) (E). Data represent the mean ¬± SEM. *P¬†<¬†0.5. Freidman test (ANOVA) with a Dunn‚Äôs post hoc multiple comparisons test compared with DMSO control. Abbreviation: CTLA‚Äê4, cytotoxic T‚Äêlymphocyte‚Äêassociated protein 4.

sec.title: GS‚Äê9688 Significantly Decreases Monocytic MDSC Frequencies, While Triggering a Release of Arginase‚ÄêI From PMN‚ÄêMDSCs
sec.p: First, we assessed the effect of GS‚Äê9688 on the frequency of MDSC subsets in patients with CHB, defining PMN‚ÄêMDSCs as CD11b+CD33+HLA‚ÄêDRloCD14‚àíCD15+ and M‚ÄêMDSCs as CD11b+CD33+HLA‚ÄêDRloCD14+CD15‚àí (gating strategy found in Supporting Fig. S6A). The ex vivo frequency of each MDSC subset was quantified as a percentage of the immature myeloid compartment (CD11bhiCD33+), revealing that M‚ÄêMDSCs are the predominant subset, accounting for approximately 45% of immature myeloid precursors (Supporting Fig. S6B). In line with previous reports with other TLR8 agonists, short‚Äêterm culture with GS‚Äê9688 led to a reduction in the frequency of M‚ÄêMDSCs (Fig. 5A and Supporting Fig. S6C). Although we noted a marked reduction in M‚ÄêMDSCs, this coincided with a relative increase in the proportion of immature myeloid cells with a PMN‚ÄêMDSC phenotype (Supporting Fig. S6C), the absolute frequency of PMN‚ÄêMDSCs remained unchanged when evaluated as a percentage of total leukocytes (Fig. 5A).

caption.p: GS‚Äê9688 skews the balance of MDSC subsets and alters their immunosuppressive potential in patients with CHB. PBMCs isolated from patients with CHB were stimulated with a single dose of 0.1¬†¬µM GS‚Äê9688 or vehicle control (DMSO) for 18¬†hours. (A) Percentage of PMN‚ÄêMDSCs (CD11b+CD33+HLA‚ÄêDRloCD14‚àíCD15+) and M‚ÄêMDSCs (CD11b+CD33+HLA‚ÄêDRloCD14+CD15‚àí) as a percentage of total live leukocytes (n¬†=¬†26; Wilcoxon signed‚Äêrank t test). PMN‚ÄêMDSC and M‚ÄêMDSC expression of CD80 (MFI; n¬†=¬†11) (B), intracellular arginase‚ÄêI (C), and CD63 (MFI; n¬†=¬†10) (D) (all Wilcoxon signed‚Äêrank t tests). (E) Extracellular arginase‚ÄêI concentration released into cell culture supernatant measured by ELISA (n¬†=¬†11). PMN‚ÄêMDSC and M‚ÄêMDSC expression of galectin‚Äê9 (MFI; n¬†=¬†10) (F) and PD‚ÄêL1 (MFI; n¬†=¬†10) (G) (both Wilcoxon signed‚Äêrank t tests). Error bars represent the mean ¬± SEM. **P¬†<¬†0.01; ***P¬†<¬†0.001; ****P¬†<¬†0.0001.

sec.title: Discussion
Author Contributions
sec.p: L.J.P., S.D., S.P.F., and M.K.M. contributed to the study concept. O.E.A., E.J.C., L.J.P., L.P., C.F., S.D., S.P.F., and M.K.M. contributed to the experimental designs. E.J.C., J.D., S.K., D.R., D.P., R.C., H.J., H.M.S., S.L., A.P., C.F., and S.D. contributed to the data generation. O.E.A., E.J.C., L.J.P., L.P., C.F., H.J., and S.D. contributed to the data analysis. W.M.C.R. and M.K.M. obtained the clinical samples. O.E.A. and L.J.P. drafted the manuscript. All authors provided critical review of the manuscript.

ack.title: Acknowledgment
ack.p: The authors thank all patients who participated in this study as well as clinical colleagues at the Royal London Hospital (Mortimer Market Center), Royal Free Hospital, and the National Institute for Medical Research University College London Hospital Biomedical Research Center (London, United Kingdom), who helped with participant recruitment, sample acquisition, and provision of clinical information. In particular, we thank Colette Sitali, clinical research nurse at the Royal Free Hospital, for her help with the sample provision. We also acknowledge the support staff at the Division of Infection and Immunity, University College London Flow Cytometry Core Facility, and the National Institutes of Health Tetramer Core Facility at Emory University (Atlanta, Georgia).
